results.title: Bangers. Feeling sexy
results.creator_credit: Davida Allen, Andrew Upton, Glenys Rowe, Cate Blanchett, Pacific Film and Television Commission. and Binnaburra Film Company
results.brief_description: Bangers (1998, 9 min)- Julie-Anne (Cate Blanchett) comes home from a hard day at the office to discover that her mother (Lynette Curran) has locked the cat in the house all day and that she is expected to cook ‘bangers’ for dinner. Preparing the meal becomes a manifestation of all the repressed tension in Julie-Anne’s work and home life. “Feeling sexy” (1998, 50 min)- This film is renowned painter Davida Allen’s first feature film. Vicki (Susie Porter) is a passionate and vivacious artist whose love for lust and life is slowly being stifled by domestic doldrums. Unable to elicit appropriate responses from her doctor husband Greg (Tamblyn Lord), Vicki embarks on a carnal affair with art student Hugo. When Vicki confesses her indiscretion to Greg, punishment comes in the shape of a blue-heeler who nearly destroys the house and Vicki’s psyche. Novelty being the spice of life, Vicki will have to call on all the resources of her creativity and imagination to coax Greg along on the path to restoring their relationship.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Davida Allen, Andrew Upton, Glenys Rowe, Cate Blanchett, Pacific Film and Television Commission. and Binnaburra Film Company

results.title: Bananas in pyjamas: surf's up
results.creator_credit: Di Drew, Tammy Burnstock and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: B1 and B2, are the much loved “Bananas in Pyjamas” who get up to a little mischief and lots of fun with their friends “The Teddies” on Cuddles Avenue. The ten fun-filled stories featuring the Bananas, the Teddies and a giant rat called “Rat in a hat” are: “Surf’s up”, “Dancing shoes”, “King rat”, “Snow storm”, “Say cheese”, “Spring clean”, “Rat post”, “Model bananas”, “Rat wash” and “Super bananas”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Di Drew, Tammy Burnstock and Australian Broadcasting Corporation

results.title: Bangarra Dance Theatre: ochres
results.creator_credit: Stephen Burstow, ABC-TV (Australia) and Bangarra Dance Theatre
results.brief_description: Recorded during the 1996 Festival of Perth, this production is an exemplary work from the dancers and musicians of the Bangarra Dance Theatre Company, Australia, acclaimed for its fusion of contemporary dance and indigenous traditional styles as well as original musical scores. The performance is centred around the substance Ochres, a material with both physical and spiritual purposes in traditional and urban Aboriginal culture, and from which Stephen Page drew inspiration for his original creation of the choreography for the production in 1994. The dance performance is structured around the characteristics, qualities and variety of symbolic significances of the substance. Divided into 5 parts, it begins with the spirit of Ochres, ‘the light’, then the performance shifts to a study of Ochres’ four essential colours; yellow, black, red and white. The performance features Bangarra Dance Theatre Company artists Gary Lang, Marilyn Miller, Djakapurra Munyarryun, Russell Page, Albert David, Kathryn Dunn, Frances Rings and Gina Rings in a seamless video capture of a powerful dance work.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stephen Burstow, ABC-TV (Australia) and Bangarra Dance Theatre

results.title: Banduk
results.creator_credit: Di Drew, Penelope Spence and National Nine Network
results.brief_description: Banduk, a young Aboriginal girl, and her friends discover that the “friendly” proprietors of an ice-cream van are smuggling native animals, including the sacred red-collared parakeet, out of Australia. This delightful story was filmed on location in Arnhem Land.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Di Drew, Penelope Spence and National Nine Network

results.title: Bandit Queen
results.creator_credit: Shekhar Kapur, Sundeep S Bedi, Kaleidoscope and Film Four International
results.brief_description: This movie tells the “true story” of Phoolan Devi, the Indian bandit queen who was arrested in the state of Uttar Pradesh in 1983 for kidnapping and murder and was freed in 1994 because of a change in government. As a young girl she questioned the caste restrictions around her, is married at 13 but leaves the village and her marriage in search of independence. As a young woman she is captivated by Vikram, a bandit gang member. His gang kidnaps and rapes her, Vikram kills the leader and assumes leadership with Devi. Vikram is eventually killed in a dispute over leadership after SriRam returns from prison. Initially Devi is driven by seeking vengeance over the death of her lover, but after being gang raped by SriRam in her own village she is seeking revenge for herself. This culminates in the Behmai Massacre of February 1981. Cast includes Seema Biswas, Nirmal Pandey and Govind Namdeo.

results.title: Bananas in pyjamas: monster bananas
results.creator_credit: Tony Tilse, Helena Harris and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: B1 and B2, the Teddies and the Rat-in-the-hat are up to their old tricks in ten different stories: “Goldilocks Bananas”, “Magic Carpet”, “Wibbly Wobbly”, “Monster Bananas”, “Morgan’s Cubby”, “Ratmobile”, “Strictly Bananas”, “Shadow Painting”, “Banana Shop” and “Mirror Mirror.” Some of the escapades include B1 and B2 disguising themselves as sea-monsters when they find some seaweed on the beach and their crazy attempts at carpentry where they try to mend furniture but end up redesigning it instead!

results.title: Bananas in pyjamas: it's music time!
results.creator_credit: Tony Tilse, Sophia Turkiewicz, Helena Harris and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: B1 and B2 and their friends the Teddies embark on eight terrific adventures. Includes two fun filled songs as well as the famous “Bananas in pyjamas” signature song. All the episodes have a musical theme.

results.title: Bananas in pyjamas birthday special
results.brief_description: The bananas, B1 and B2 and the teddies Amy, Lulu and Morgan have lots of fun together and they get up to lots of mischief as well. “Cuddles Avenue” - the naughty bananas decide to play a trick on the teddies. “Birthday Week” - it’s the bananas’ birthday on Friday and the excitement builds as the teddies prepare a surprise party. “Wet Paint” - Amy and Morgan can’t resist touching the brand new paint of the park bench, just to see if it is really wet. “Fancy Dress” - the bananas and teddies have been invited to a fancy dress party.

results.title: Ballads of Bullant Ridge. No. 1
results.creator_credit: Chris Gallagher, Alan Marshall, Ronald Mason and Academy Film Productions
results.brief_description: A series of bush ballad songs based on the “Speewa Jack” characters from the Alan Marshall stories illustrated by cartoonist Douglas Trainsh. The songs are ‘The Strongest man in town’; ‘The Boxing kangaroo’; and ‘Goanna oil’.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Chris Gallagher, Alan Marshall, Ronald Mason and Academy Film Productions

results.title: Bamboozled [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Spike Lee, Jon Kilik and 40 Acres and a Mule Filmworks
results.brief_description: Shot on digital video (by cinematographer Ellen Kuras) and taking it’s title from a Malcolm X speech (“You’ve been led astray, led amok, you’ve been bamboozled”), Spike Lee’s “Bamboozled” is an ambitious and contentious satire, a dazzling balancing act that at times strains under it’s own ingenuity but never fails to provoke and challenge. Damon Wayans stars as a successful and affected television executive, Pierre Delacroix, who is pressured by his wannabe home-boy boss (Michael Rapaport) to create a hit series tailored for African Americans. Frustrated by the implicit racism that dominates the entertainment industry, Delacroix comes up with a show that he feels white America really wants to see, a minstrel show called ‘Mantan - The New Millennium Minstrel Show’. His offensive joke backfires however when ‘Mantan’ becomes a runaway success. Lee takes firm pot shots at various institutions, interspersing the film with racially coded advertising and racist images from America’s shameful filmic past (including much loved American classics, “Birth of a nation” and “Gone with the wind”). Not surprising then that Lee dedicates the film to Budd Schulberg, the writer of Eliza Kazan’s 1957 media satire, “A face in the crowd”. Cast includes Jada Pinkett-Smith, Savion Glover and Tommy Davidson.
